name: Tech Meeting Conversations
description: Common conversational pairs and phrases used in technical meetings, from stand-ups to code reviews.

conversation.text: Is the pull request ready for review?
Almost. I'm just running the unit tests one last time.

cards.note: A 'Pull Request' (PR) is a formal request to merge code into a shared repository. 'Unit tests' are small tests that verify a specific piece of code works as expected.

conversation.text: We need to address the technical debt in this module.
I agree. Let's create a ticket for refactoring after this release.

cards.note: 'Technical debt' is the implied cost of rework caused by choosing an easy (limited) solution now instead of using a better approach that would take longer. 'Refactoring' is restructuring existing computer code without changing its external behavior.

conversation.text: What's your bandwidth for the next sprint?
I can probably take on one major story and a couple of smaller bug fixes.

cards.note: 'Bandwidth' in a business context refers to a person's capacity to take on more work. In Agile, a 'sprint' is a fixed time period where a team works to complete a set amount of work.

conversation.text: The staging environment is down.
On it. I'm checking the deployment logs now.

cards.note: A 'staging environment' is a near-exact replica of the production environment, used for final testing before a new release. 'On it' is a common, concise way to say 'I am starting to work on that problem right now.'

conversation.text: Let's table this discussion and take it offline.
Good idea. I'll set up a follow-up meeting with the infrastructure team.

cards.note: To 'table a discussion' means to postpone it. To 'take it offline' means to discuss it outside of the current meeting, usually with a smaller group.

conversation.text: Can you sync up with the backend developer on this?
Sure, I'll ping him on Slack right away.

cards.note: To 'sync up' means to align and share the latest information. To 'ping' someone is to send them a quick digital message, often to get their attention.

conversation.text: The API is returning a 500 error.
I see it. Looks like a null pointer exception on the server.

cards.note: A '500 Internal Server Error' is a generic error message indicating that something went wrong on the website's server. A 'null pointer exception' is a common programming error that occurs when a program tries to use an object reference that is null (or empty).

conversation.text: I've pushed my changes to the feature branch.
Great, I'll pull them down and resolve the merge conflicts.

cards.note: In Git, 'pushing' sends your local changes to a remote repository. A 'feature branch' isolates work on a new feature. 'Pulling' fetches changes from the remote. 'Merge conflicts' occur when Git can't automatically resolve differences in code between two branches.

conversation.text: We need to scope out the requirements for the new dashboard.
Let's start by creating user stories for the MVP.

cards.note: To 'scope out' means to define the boundaries and details of a project. 'User stories' are informal, general explanations of a software feature written from the perspective of the end user. 'MVP' stands for Minimum Viable Product.

conversation.text: The build failed in the CI/CD pipeline.
It seems like a dependency issue. Let me investigate.

cards.note: A 'CI/CD pipeline' (Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment) is an automated process for building, testing, and deploying code. A 'dependency' is an external software component that a project relies on to work.

conversation.text: Are there any blockers for this task?
Yes, I'm waiting for the API keys from the third-party service.

cards.note: In project management, a 'blocker' is anything that prevents a team member from completing a task. This is a very common question in daily stand-up meetings.

conversation.text: Let's do a quick sanity check on this.
Okay. The logic seems sound, and the UI is responsive.

cards.note: A 'sanity check' is a quick, basic test to ensure that a feature or calculation produces results that make sense. It's not exhaustive but helps catch major, obvious flaws.

conversation.text: The production database is under heavy load.
We should optimize the query that's causing the bottleneck.

cards.note: A 'bottleneck' is a point in a system that slows down the overall performance. Optimizing a database 'query' means rewriting it to be more efficient and faster.

conversation.text: This seems like a workaround, not a permanent fix.
It is. We'll prioritize a proper solution in the next development cycle.

cards.note: A 'workaround' is a temporary solution to bypass a problem. It's also sometimes called a 'patch' or a 'hotfix'. It's important to distinguish these from long-term, robust solutions.

conversation.text: Could you do a peer review on my code?
Sure, send me the link to the pull request.

cards.note: A 'peer review' or 'code review' is the practice of having another developer examine your code for bugs, style issues, and logic errors before it is merged into the main codebase.

conversation.text: We've found a critical bug in production.
All hands on deck. We need to roll back the last deployment immediately.

cards.note: 'All hands on deck' is an idiom meaning everyone needs to help. To 'roll back' a deployment means to revert to a previous, stable version of the application.

conversation.text: The user is experiencing a caching issue.
Have them try a hard refresh or clearing their browser cache.

cards.note: A 'caching issue' happens when a user's browser stores an old version of a file (like a script or stylesheet). A 'hard refresh' (Ctrl+Shift+R) forces the browser to re-download all files from the server.

conversation.text: Is this feature backward compatible?
Yes, we've designed the new API endpoint to not break older client versions.

cards.note: 'Backward compatible' means a new version of a system can still work with older versions of itself or other components. This is critical for mobile apps where not all users update at the same time.

conversation.text: I'm having trouble reproducing the bug locally.
Let's try to replicate the exact steps from the bug report together.

cards.note: To 'reproduce a bug' means to be able to reliably trigger it by following a specific set of steps. If a bug can't be reproduced, it's very difficult to fix. 'Locally' means on the developer's own computer.

conversation.text: What are the action items from this meeting?
John will investigate the database performance, and I will draft the project proposal.

cards.note: 'Action items' are specific, defined tasks assigned to one or more people, to be completed after a meeting. They are the concrete outcomes of a discussion.

conversation.text: This ticket is blocked pending design approval.
I'll follow up with the UI/UX designer to get the mockups.

cards.note: 'Pending' means waiting for. 'Mockups' are static, high-fidelity designs that show what a feature will look like. UI/UX stands for User Interface/User Experience.

conversation.text: Let's avoid scope creep on this project.
Agreed. Any new feature requests must go through the formal change request process.

cards.note: 'Scope creep' (or feature creep) is when a project's requirements expand uncontrollably beyond their original goals, often leading to delays and budget overruns.

conversation.text: We need a post-mortem for the server outage.
Okay, I'll schedule it and prepare the timeline of events.

cards.note: A 'post-mortem' (from Latin, 'after death') is a process to analyze an incident (like a server outage) to understand what happened, what went wrong, and how to prevent it from happening again.

conversation.text: Make sure to add comments to your code.
Will do. I'll document the complex logic in the payment module.

cards.note: 'Will do' is a common, affirmative response meaning 'I will do that'. Documenting code is crucial for maintainability, making it easier for other developers (or your future self) to understand.

conversation.text: Let's move this to the back of the backlog.
Understood. I'll de-prioritize it for now.

cards.note: The 'backlog' in Agile is the master list of all desired features and fixes for a product. Moving a task to the back means it has a very low priority.

conversation.text: The code freeze for the release is this Friday.
Roger that. No more new features, only critical bug fixes until then.

cards.note: A 'code freeze' is a period when no new changes are made to a codebase, to ensure stability before a major release. 'Roger that' is a way to say 'I understand'.

conversation.text: This feature feels like gold plating.
I agree. It's a nice-to-have, but not essential for the MVP.

cards.note: 'Gold plating' refers to adding extra, unnecessary features to a product that the client didn't ask for and that increase complexity and cost. 'Nice-to-have' is a common term for non-essential features.

conversation.text: We need to run a regression test before deploying.
Right. We have to ensure the new changes didn't break existing functionality.

cards.note: 'Regression testing' is the process of re-running functional and non-functional tests to ensure that previously developed and tested software still performs correctly after a change.

conversation.text: Can you provide the steps to reproduce?
Sure. First, log in as a standard user, then navigate to the settings page...

cards.note: 'Steps to reproduce' (often abbreviated as 'STR') are a clear, sequential list of actions required to trigger a specific bug. They are essential for a good bug report.

conversation.text: Let's wrap up this meeting.
Okay. I'll send out the meeting minutes shortly.

cards.note: To 'wrap up' means to finish or conclude. 'Meeting minutes' are a written record of the key discussions, decisions, and action items from a meeting.
